content: The "Servicemembers Access to Justice Act of 2008" allows for waiver of sovereign immunity under the 11th Amendment for enforcement of USERRA. The "Servicemembers Access to Justice Act of 2008" allows for waiver of State sovereign immunity under the 11th Amendment for enforcement of USERRA. Section 4323 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to allow actions against a State to be brought in federal or state courts. The "Servicemembers Access to Justice Act of 2008" amends Section 4323 of title 38, United States Code, allowing waiver of State sovereign immunity for enforcement of USERRA. A State's receipt of Federal financial assistance constitutes a waiver of sovereign immunity to suits brought by employees or applicants in a program authorized by this chapter. The "Servicemembers Access to Justice Act of 2008" amends Section 4323 of title 38, United States Code, allowing waiver of State sovereign immunity for enforcement of USERRA. It applies to individuals seeking rights or benefits under this chapter in a program or activity as defined in the Age Discrimination Act of 1975. The amendments made by the "Servicemembers Access to Justice Act of 2008" apply to any failure to comply with Chapter 43 of Title 38, United States Code, before or after the enactment date. It also applies to actions or complaints filed under Chapter 43 that are initiated after the enactment date. SEC. 3. UNENFORCEABILITY OF AGREEMENTS TO ARBITRATE DISPUTES ARISING UNDER USERRA. Section 4327 of title 38, United States Code, prohibits arbitration agreements between employers and employees for disputes under this chapter, except in cases where both parties agree to arbitration after a dispute arises. Exceptions to the prohibition on arbitration agreements under Section 4327 of title 38, United States Code, include situations where parties agree to arbitration after a dispute arises and the enforcement of rights in a valid collective bargaining agreement. Validity and enforcement of this section regarding arbitration clauses are determined by Federal law. The validity and enforcement of arbitration clauses under a valid collective bargaining agreement are determined by Federal law. The court, not the arbitrator, decides on the validity or enforceability of an agreement to arbitrate. This section applies to all contracts between an employer and an employee. The section challenges the agreement to arbitrate in contracts between employers and employees, applying to all agreements before or after the enactment date. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the chapter. Section 4327 of title 38, United States Code, makes agreements to arbitrate disputes unenforceable. It applies to any violations of chapter 43 of title 38, regardless of when they occurred, and to all pending actions or complaints under chapter 43. Additionally, enhanced remedies for enforcing USERRA are provided in Section 4. Section 4323(d) of title 38, United States Code, is amended to include compensation or damages, expand the scope of violations, and enhance remedies for enforcing USERRA. The amendment to Section 4323(d) of title 38, United States Code expands the scope of violations and enhances remedies for enforcing USERRA by including compensation or damages for any person affected by a State or private employer who violates the provisions of this chapter. The amendment to Section 4323(d) of title 38, United States Code enhances remedies for enforcing USERRA by holding State or private employers liable for damages, including wages, benefits, and monetary losses, to any person affected by violations of the chapter. The amendment to Section 4323(d) of title 38, United States Code enhances remedies for enforcing USERRA by holding employers liable for damages, including monetary losses, interest, and liquidated damages. The court may award liquidated damages not to exceed 100 percent of the compensation or damages awarded under subparagraph (A) if the employer proves good faith and reasonable grounds for believing no violation occurred. The court may award liquidated damages not exceeding 100 percent of the compensation or damages awarded under subparagraph (A) if no violation of the provisions of this chapter is found. In any action under this section, the court may require the employer to comply with the provisions of this chapter. Additionally, in the case of a violation of the provisions of this chapter, punitive damages may be awarded. In cases of violations by employers with 25 or more employees, punitive damages may be required if the violation was done with malice or reckless indifference. The right to a jury trial is also granted in such cases. In cases of violations by employers with 25 or more employees, punitive damages may be required if the violation was done with malice or reckless indifference. The right to a jury trial is granted to a person who commences an action under this section. Federal government employers found in violation will face orders from the Board for compliance. The Board can order a Federal agency to comply with employment provisions and compensate a person for any lost wages or benefits due to violations. The Board can order a Federal agency to compensate a person for lost wages or benefits due to violations, including actual monetary losses, interest, and liquidated damages. The Board can order a Federal agency to compensate a person for lost wages or benefits due to violations, including actual monetary losses, interest, and liquidated damages calculated at prevailing rates over the period. An additional amount as liquidated damages is also awarded, equal to the sum of the calculated damages and interest, or $10,000, whichever is greater, unless the agency proves the violation was in good faith with reasonable grounds. The Office of Personnel Management can award liquidated damages not exceeding 100 percent of compensation or damages awarded, if it is proven that the violation was in good faith with reasonable grounds. The amendments apply to Federal agencies for compensation of lost wages or benefits due to violations. The amendments allow for liquidated damages up to 100 percent of compensation or damages awarded for violations of chapter 43 of title 38, United States Code. These amendments apply to all actions filed under chapter 43 after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. REQUIRED AWARD OF ATTORNEY FEES IN ACTIONS TO ENFORCE PROVISIONS OF USERRA. The amendments require mandatory enforcement of rights with respect to state or private employers and federal executive agencies under title 38, United States Code. The changes apply to any violations of chapter 43 of title 38, regardless of when they occurred. The amendments mandate enforcement of rights under title 38, US Code for state, private employers, and federal agencies. They apply to violations of chapter 43, regardless of timing, including actions pending enactment. SEC. 6. CLARIFYING THE DEFINITION OF ``SUCCESSOR IN INTEREST''. The term "successor in interest" is defined for purposes of subparagraph (A)(iv) in a multifactor test considering factors like continuity of business operations, plant usage, workforce continuity, job similarity, and supervisory personnel similarity. The term "successor in interest" is defined for purposes of subparagraph (A)(iv) in a multifactor test considering factors like continuity of business operations, plant usage, workforce continuity, job similarity, supervisory personnel similarity, machinery, equipment, production methods, products, or services. The successor's lack of notice or awareness of a potential claim at the time of a merger, acquisition, or other form of succession is not considered in the multifactor test. The amendment states that a successor's lack of notice of a potential claim during a merger or acquisition will not be considered in the multifactor test. This amendment applies to any violations of chapter 43 of title 38, United States Code, before or after the enactment of the Act, and to all pending actions or complaints under chapter 43. The amendment applies to violations of chapter 43 of title 38, United States Code, before or after the enactment of the Act, and to all pending actions or complaints under chapter 43. SEC. 7. USERRA has no statute of limitations. No statute of limitations applies to any proceeding under chapter 43 of title 38, United States Code, including actions or complaints filed before or after the enactment of this Act. The Act removes any statute of limitations for non-compliance or violations of chapter 43 of title 38, United States Code, regardless of when they occurred. It also applies to all pending actions or complaints under chapter 43. SEC. 8 clarifies that USERRA prohibits wage discrimination against members of the armed forces. Section 4303(2) of title 38, United States Code is amended to include wages or salary. The amendment applies to any violations of chapter 43 of title 38, regardless of when they occurred. Additionally, equitable relief is required when appropriate. Section 4323(e) of title 38, United States Code is amended to require the court to use reemployment denial as irreparable harm when considering issuing an injunction or restraining order. The court must consider reemployment denial as irreparable harm when deciding on issuing an injunction or restraining order. An employer's denial of reemployment constitutes irreparable harm, and there is a presumption of harm to the person denied reemployment. The court must consider reemployment denial as irreparable harm when deciding on issuing an injunction or restraining order. There is a rebuttable presumption that the harm to a person denied reemployment outweighs the harm to their employer if an injunction is not issued. Additionally, there is a rebuttable presumption in favor of issuing an injunction to reinstate a person denied reemployment when considering public interest or policy. The court must consider reemployment denial as irreparable harm when deciding on issuing an injunction. There is a rebuttable presumption in favor of reinstating a person denied reemployment for public interest or policy reasons. The amendments apply to violations of chapter 43 of title 38, before or after the enactment of this Act. The amendments apply to any failure to comply with or violation of chapter 43 of title 38, United States Code, before, on, or after the enactment of this Act, as well as to actions or complaints pending under chapter 43 on or after the enactment of this Act.
